div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,550] ALEXANDRIA, Friday, JULY 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p:
Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
London £ 14. 5/ £ 9.
Maresilles £ 9. 15/ £ 6 15/
Brindisi £ 6. 15/
-
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 30 for Dover.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 11 for Devonport.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 18 for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS< BANKERS
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 20 June, 4 and 18 July, 1 and 15 Augsut, 5.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.

First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach. Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Represented at Hamburg by the Norddeutsche Bank in Hamburg.
The bank transacts general banking business of every description and acts as representative of the following foreign banks:

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The N. westerly breeze which has been blowing almost continually for the last month, veered round yesterday to the N.E. The heat and the humidity have increased. This morning opens very sultry. There is a light northerly breeze and a falling harometer. Some wind may be expected towards the close of the day.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Friday, July 20, 1906.
A DANGEROUS SCHEME.

It is sufficient to say of Mr. Haldane's new Army scheme that it more than realizes the worst rebodings to which expression has been given, says the “Globe.” Two battalions of the Gnards and eight battalions of the L'oe are-'o he disbanded. The existing number of 6eld batteries is apparently to be retained, bat their home establishment is to be reduced to a four-gnu basis, except eighteen that are to be put, for some mysterious reason, on a two- gun basis. The net result is a redaction of 3.800 mood in the Riling Artillery, doom pained by an extraordinary arrangement under which certain Militia regiments are to be converted from garrison to Geld artillery, with a view* of supplying the ammnnitim columns to the brigade divisions, and of firm in a Reserve of,gnnnera and drivera. At the time the release of a certain number of ninth of the Regular Garrison Artillery from the dettes of coast defense will allow of their absorption in the Field. The whole of the Militia—Infantry, Artillery, had Beginners -is to be rendered liable to be sent On foreign service, which entails, we • appose, the Goal disappearance of the Militia Ballot, The Volunteers are to be er outraged by the receipt of the abandoned Geld gun*, which Mr. Haldane thinks might be useful in the case of a raid by a Eu rope un Power, and the whole Volunteer force is to be brought into connection with some local authority, -of which the country is to be the unit The details ot this last innovation are still in the dark, and Mr. Haldane Was unable to enlighten the House as to the footings, powers, and constitution of those bodies. Although a total rendition of 20,000 in the Regular AYfny is premised, Mr. Haldane, with the assent outlie) Army Connoil, undertakes to have ready for war an expeditionary force of 160.t)0 \ of wh .m 60,000 msn. will be with the oolongs at home, 70.000 will be Reservists, and the remaining 80,010 mo bilised Militia. The army corps organization is abolished in favor of six big division! of, infantry, containing three brigade! each, after the Indian pattern, four cavalry brigades, and a full complement of artillery, the whole to form a force larger by nearly a third than has hitherto been contemplated for purpose outside the United Kingdom.

0f the disappearance of the term Army Corps we bag no partial complaint to make: it is of German origin; it never Gutted in with oar pa^ system, sod was float to the wind* in time ot war. 'And if a reduction was to be made in the ranks of the Regular Army, it was obvious that the infantry most bus the «offeror* : #vend so, we regret that Mr. Haldane did not are his way to ratio tip cadres of the disappearing battalions rather than resort to the drastic prosoma of disbandment And we think the redaction of the Guards a moat grave error, doe apparently to tome absurd piece of sentiment Bat it' is against interference with the Artillery that we ieel bound to otter the strongest protest of which the language is capable. Mr. Hildaoe gave the film«y pretext that andante pre-sent system only half the existing batteries could be mobilized for want of man and of ammunition columns. Aa Mr. Balfout pointed out in an admirable piece of criticism, a large proportion of these batteries are ot new creation, and time has not yet permitted of the growth of a sufficient Reserve. But this is accumulating year by year, and while nearly 4,000 artillerymen are to be dismissed, Mr. Haldane alters the terms of servi6* for new reaerate, substituting six yean with the toolbars and fix with the Reserve for the present period of three and nine The combination of those two changea most bring about a rapid and automation fall in the number of men annually joining the Reserve The molt its large diminution in the amount of trained artillery experts available for service at home and abroad, in men, moreover, who on neither be improvised or replaced. The makeshift of potting in Militia and Garrison Artillery to assist the Geld batteries is an expedient which we regard with the gravest suspension. Any reference to modem campaign* will show that the ammunition columns require skill and experience discreetly second to what is demanded in the batteries themselves; and the mingling of men trained under diffare’.t conditions and with totally different experiences is bound to introduce a fatal confusion. Mr. Haldane has been guided apparently by the standard of success attained in on# or two picked Militia regiments. WA are afraid he has tens the victim of a generalization based on exceptions. The red notion of the Artillery in South Africa in the face of a native rising, aid the denudation of oar moat important foreign garrisons, IA an act of sheer madness.

Nor does the ’Globe” feel any real oonGdenoe hat Mr.Haldane has secured the 150,000 men for his expeditionary force: his Genres are aim- (vulgarly unconvincing. As we have eo long, been the victim of paper anniee, we may be exoneèd if we hesitate to believe that the present secretary for War has solved the problem that baa be filed all his predecessors. Wa are still met by the old question, when is the British sol tier to come from? The gnat fact remains» that at a moment when the armies outbid- world are striving feverishly to 'ïàoraase their numbers and efficiency, and when the future is black with this prao tical oratory of a straggle for oar national existence, Mr. Haldane proposes to redo the effective strength of the Iritish Army by 20,000 men. The net saving, •o far as we can gather, is to be about a million a year, a windfall which is certain to be appropriated by some crazy fad of modern de moor tie Glance. And was have no guarantee that what is taken eff the shoulders of the not be replaced on those of the ratepayer by the County Associations. These bodies are nebulous for the present, send the utmost we on hype about them is that they will do of harm to the auxiliary forces the probability is that they will be in some shape or other an emanation of tabs County Cannoli. It is ’-perfectly ’notorious that many ot those bodies, all the Welsh tance, that of the West Riding of Yorkshire, and the London County Council itself, are opposed root and branch to what they oil militarism. To a substantial section of the Radical party the British uniform is hateful, the British officer a gilded popinjay. To place the destinies of the metropolitan volunteer’s node the control of the parochial politicians IA ffyiDg Garden» I* a piece of mere lonely ; but if this IA not contemplated. what does Mr. Haldane mean t of all tabs items in h’s disappointing, disheartening, and dangerous programmed, there IA none that will be regarded with moresnspioion than this tampering with the Auxiliary Forces.
Mr. Goodman,, inspector in the Public Health Department, has left for Upper Egypt, where he will inspect the ‘Lffioes of the department.
To-day’s plague bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, the patient-being* young native living at Ли el Tin. Two recoveries are reported from Bibeh.
It is said-that Hussein - Pasha Moharrem, A’D.C/'tti H.H.'the Khedive, will probably be appointed Emir El Hag for the 190<> pilgrim- age in place of Ibrahim Pasha Fathi.
The cinematograph is certainly a success, and is much appreciated by.* large crowd who can. en jo jb the several, delights of sea breeze, mneio.-and tableaux under -one-canvas.

The body of a native .was. found -a few days ago in the Bagonrleb Canal, near Birrs Eb Lyan, Menonfieh, with a shot wound in bis body. The murdered man was baried before identification and the murder remain a mystery.

The annual distribution of prizes at this school will take place on Sunday nexf, 22nd inst., at 4 30 p.m., under the presidency of M. P. Girard, French Consul-General. An excellent musical and dramatic programme has been arranged for the afternoon, and includes a drama entitled-- King Alfred and a ore-act operetta Le Premier Triomphe de Duguesclin, 'which will be taken part in’ by the pupils.

Two days ego a Greek was found, by the police, dead in a dosed i hop in the Darbel Ahmar quarter, Cairo. The post-mortem ex>animation-showed that death had taken place six days- before the door of the shop was opened*; the’ police who were dnty in the street were not aware of the fact till the body had reached an advanced stage of decomposition. The body, which canid not be identified, was handed over to the Hellenic consular authorities.

About 6 o’clock yesterday evening, a young European woman was seen to rash towards the quay wall in the eastern harbor, with the evident intention of throwing herself iotd the water. A coastguardsman who happened to .be near by promptly laid hands on her! and prevented her from, carrying her mad project into practice. -Meanwhile -the relative* of the young woman, who is married, appeared on the scene and she was escorted by them back to her booze, from which the had fled in her dressing gown.

We were' privileged last-evening to attend a general rehearsal at the Z-zinia, Theatre of a orientate phono, exhibition. This kind of entertainment, which m a combination of the oine-:marte graph and phonograph worked simultaneously, is by no means new to ns, bat judging| from whit we saw of the repertoire, a very enjoyable entertainment will he provided for the public. la oar opinion-, there is still considerable scope for improvements in the working of the cinema phono, bat the performance aa given at -the- -Z'ziuia is without doubt np to date, and is as effective and perfect as is possible with the, apparatus of the present day. Selections from varions joperas and comio songs were very effectively reproduced. The cinematograph piotnres were - far above the average and were reproduced with sharpness and an entire science of flickering, which was doubt- less a revelation -to many. » Notable among these may be mentioned the marriage of the King of Spain and the coronation of the King and Queen of Norway. Another most accept- able pioture was that of a ship in a stormy sea. This was accompanied by a very realistic imitation of the sound of the waves and plunging of the vessel. The large audience appeared extremely- pleased with the fare provided, and many of the pictures were heartily applauded. We can thoroughly recommend the entertainment as being a most excellent one.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.B. Mgr, Photiup, Orthodox-Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, leaves to-day for Cairo.
Mr. Douglas Dnnlop, Adviser to the Ministry of Education, is expected to return from leave on the 17th prox.
We learn with regret of the decease of the Dowager Conntees de Collalto, mother of our popular and esteemed confrère, Count Max di Collalto, Editor of the “Progrès.” Our sincere condolences.

M. Pascalingo, judge of the Court of First Instance at Athens, arrives here to-morrow from the Piræns. M Pascalingo will hold an “instruction” in several cases pending, notably the Callioopoulo affair and the Fashn tragedy.
Mohamed Bey Suleiman, private secretary to the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior, has been granted 70 days’ leaue, dating from the 26th inst.
Mr. F. W. Simond, Bâtonnier of the Order of Advocates of Egypt, leaves for Europe this afternoon.
Berlin, July 19.

The “Kidnische Zeitung” states that the Anglo German Commission, sitting here, has concluded the delimitation of the northern frontier of German East Africa. A complete agreement has been reached. With few alterations, the existing border has been adopted, on account of geological, commercial, and tribunal (1 tribal) conditions. (Reuter)
A DENIAL.
Berlin, July 19.

It is officially announced that the statement appearing in certain French newspapers regarding a German expedition to the Tripoli hinterland organized by Baron Von Oppenheim with' the object of establishing relatione with the Sennsei,. is devoid of foundation. (R.)
DEFIANT CHIEFS.
Durban, July 19.
A portion of the Natal force is shortly -moving south in order to deal with a Couple of defiant chiefs.' ( Reuter)
London, July 19.
The Government gave general support to the Natal Government in yesterday evening’s debate. Unionist papers accept with satisfaction the Natal Government’s explanations. ( Reuter)
JAPANESE AND BRITISH TRADE.
London, July 19.

House of Commons.-Sir E. Grey stated that the Government was making enqniriea with regard to- the allegations that the Japan- ese were hampering British trade in Manchuria. The whole question, he said, was receiving attention. (Reuter)
THE HARVEST IN DANGER.
St. Peteresburg, July 19.

Peasants burned fifteen properties in the immediate vicinity of the town of Voronesh on Sunday, in broad daylight. Owing to the strike of Polish agrarian laborers the harvest is in danger of being lost. Wholesale murders of policemen are taking place in the province and town Lablin. Ten of them were shot in the latter, place. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, July 19.
Regarding the Agrarian Question, the Duma has passed a. modified amendment expressing the hope that the people will await calmly the result of its labours. The Socialists left the Chamber. (Havas)
Marseilles, July 19.
King Sisowath has embarked on his return to Cambodia. (Havas)
Paris, July 19.
M. Faîtières has left for Rambouillet (H.)

CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.
( Gazette’s Special Service. )
London, Thursday, July 19.

At the meeting held to-day of the Share- holders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, the proposal to amalgamate with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment- Company, Limited, was rejected. The latter company have consequently decided to in- crease the amount of their capital by £400,000 only.
CAPT. LYONS’ EXPEDITION.

Captain H. G. Lyons, Director of the Survey Department, who has left England on his return to Cairo, will shortly take ebarge of an important expedition- for the topographical survey of the Nile watershed. It is intended., to obtain levels as far sooth as Laka YiqtoiÂà, and thence another party will work-the-country for the same purpose right down-to-the coast.

A survey of the Nile watershed ha«-never been made, and the present soheme has been undertaken by the Egyptian. Government in connection with the : question оf greater storage of water for the need» of Lower Egypt.
Captain Lyons will have two parties at work in the course of a few weeks, one commencing almost at once from Gondokoro.

It is stated that a battalion of the Gnards (according to the “Daily Mail”), the 8rd Coldstream’s, with two line battalion* and a field battery have been ordered to hold them- selves in readiness for service in Egypt.

We have been enable this far to obtain any confirmation of the report, which, we imagine, arises from the fact that should any occurrences in Egypt unhappily make a further increase of the garrison necessary) certain units, which are first on the list for foreign service would be eent out.
Lient. Col. A. M. Mantell, C.R.E. in Egypt-, and Mrs. Mantell will.embark at;PortSaid on the P. & 0. steamer Mongolia on the 24th inst. for London.
Major J. C. Jameson, R.A.M.C., came down to Alexandria from Cairo to-day on dnty.
A board of officers assembled to-day at Alexandria to examine and report npon the present state of health of Rev. F.B.N. Nor- man-Lee, M.A., Chaplain to the Forces.

' A board of examination will -assemble at Mustapha Ре ’ barracks, Alexandria, on Wednesday, 1st August, -and following days for the purpose of superintending the examination of Captain H.F.B. Lewin, R.F.A (E.A.), and Lient. T.H.C. Frankland, 1st Royal Dublin Fusilierp, who are candidates for admission to the Staff College.
Major W. H. Rothôram, R. E., and Miss G. M. Payne, matron, Q.A I.M.N.S., have been granted leave of absence.

The death of Colonel W & Sparked C.M.G., retired list, Welsh Regiment, at the early age of forty-four, is very sad, says the “Army and' play Gazette.” It was not so long ago that 1 everybody was saying bow lucky he-was rio get ' promotion so early. Yet hie very good luck proved in the end to his disadvantage,1 for he became a colonel in the Army so early in life ( that there was -difficulty in providing for him.

In the province of Bahr el-Ghaaal his - name 1 will long be remembered -m connection -with 1 the work for the reclaiming of that region ' and bringing it back to oivih'sation. He 1 displayed great powers of organization and administration and richly earned the C.M.G. which was -conferred-upon him in acknowledgment of his services. When he * came home and settled down after his retire- 1 ment he seemed to be in robust health. The week before his death be was taken ill whilst c playing polo. Nothing maoh was thought of the matter at the time, bat on looming under medical advice bad symptoms developed, and it was soon ionnd that he was seriously ill. Notwithstanding every care and attention he grew worse, and on the 5th inst. he succumbed 1 to his malady. A correspondent writes of him: - ,£

“I knew poor Sparkes intimately, and knew t well what an earnest, good soldier he was. If I he. had stay(ji on in the Service he could not I have failed to make an even greater mark than he did, for he had all the qualities which go to euanre success ; but there is no don’t that his constitution became undermined whilst he j was toiling for the public good. His early death deprives his friends of the companion- ship of one who was popular wherever be went and capable of almost anything in the shape of hard work and responsibility.”

The bodies of the unfortunate Italian fishermen who sank with their boat off the Aboukir I coast on Monday night, as reported in our c columns, have not yet been recovered, and they are supposed to be still in the interior of the vessel. Divers have been at work endeavoring to bring the bodies to the surface, but so far without any success.
The vessel lies at the bottom of the sea and has drifted slightly towards the shore It is hoped that the work of the divers will be more successful to-day.

div.head: CAIRO RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: PASSENGER SERIOUSLY INJURED.

A railway accident took place yesterday .afternoon ora' Eonbbeh Palace, with the result that three persona were more or less severely . injured and a certain amount of damage done t to rolling stock, etc.

The express which leaves Pont Limonn at ! 1.16 p.m. was entering Koubbeh station when, through some defect in the points where Ы.Н. | the Khedive's special line branches off from the ordinary line, the engine ran - on to the Khédivial line, while aU bot the first of the carriages followed the main line.

The leading carriage was dragged along between the rails,. While the two fractions of the train which it linked, followed their respective line for some 50 yards. At this point the first- carriage, which was being dragged along at right angles to both sets of rails, crashed into the end of the passenger L .platform.. As the engine had shat-off steam, the shook not only stopped it bat sent it back; - -it ran backwards ter a short «distance bod then leaving the rails toppled over on its left side. Had it fallen to the right it .most have in- jured the remaining " carriages, which had also backed down the line towards the points in consequence of the collision of the leading oar with the end of the? platform.

The engine-driver and stoker were both injured by \the fall of the engine and were sent to hospital suffering from severe bruises and general shock. One passenger only was injured, but his injuries are very severe. Besides serious contusions, a compound fracture of the thigh was diagnosed by the doctors called up to give first aid.

It was feared last night that the victim of the accident who is believed to be a son of Yawer Bey—would have to lose the injured limb, the leg having been badly twisted at the moment of or immediately after the fracture.

The break down train composed of five carriages and a crane - arrived shortly before 3 p.m. in charge of Mr. Peaoock and within half- an-hour the line bad been cleared. Unfortunately the results of the accident persisted in a general confusion which lasted till nightfall. Trains were decayed. One is said to have taken half an-hourto get from Pont L;monn to Demerdache and another to have arrived at Pont Limonn nearly an hour late.

Looomotive No. 563, which was injured will require extensive repairs. The damage done to the carriage which collided with the end of the platform at Koubbeh. Palace station is lees considerable than might have been expected. The repairs to the permanent way were completed by 6 p.m.
An enquiry is being bald into the causes of the accident.
"AL MOAYAD” AND DENISHWAI.

“A1 Moayad” says :—“Some papers assert that the expenses of the Special Court and the pay of the employs who were engaged in the Deniahwai case amounted to LB. 12,000, which amount has been approved by the Ministry of Finance. Bat, as ferae we can judge, there must be a great exaggeration in the amount given. If we take into account all these expenses, according to the circumstances of the case, and include the fares and expenses of the Advisers and the amount paid to counsel for prosecution, the total will scarcely be more than L Б. 2,000. Of the other hand, we can never believe the rumor that the cost of cables to Loudon and the money paid to some of the London papers for producing a sensation have all been put down to the account of the Egyptian Treasury."

With regard to this insinuation made by the editor of “A1 Moayad,” we should like to remind Sheikh Aly Youssef that England is not Turkey, and that our Press is not subsidised by the Government. If Sheikh Aly Yoursef has any-proof that any British papers or their correspondents have been subsidized by the British authorities here to ipubUsb . sensational versions of the Deniehwai affair, let him give names and proofs. In the meantime we may inform “At Moayad” that the credit opened by the Ministry of Finance does not exceed L.E. 1,200).

div.head: VALI AND SHERIF.
div.p: “Al Mokattam" learns from its correspondent at Suez that differences have arisen between the Vali of the Hedjaz and the Sheriff of Mecca over the hire of oamels travelling between Mecca and Medina. The Vali is said to have advised the latter not to interfere in Arab affairs.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The following is the menu of the dinner to be served tomorrow evening, on the occasion of the inauguration of the new theatre :—
Consommé de volaille glacé
Filet de barbue à la Calaisienno
Pommes vapeur
Aloyau à la Maréchal
Chaudfroid de poularde à la Strasabourgeoiso
Fonds d’artiohaux à l’Itufionne
Dindonneau rôti à la broche
Salade de saison
Bombe tutti frutti
Petite fours assortis
Grand Dessert

div.head: THE IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK
div.p: ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

At the annual general meeting of share- holders of this bank, held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, E.C., the Bari of Beseborougb, C.V.O., C.B., presiding, the Chairman said : Gentlemen, before referring to the report and accounts, you will, I am sure, permit me to express the regret we all feel at the unavoidable absence to day through illness of our esteemed colleague, Lord Hillingdon, and we hope he will soon be with ns again, quite restored to' health. In submitting to you their forty-third annual report and accounts, showing the operations of the bank for the year 1905, the directors have every confidence that they will be regarded as quite satisfactory by the shareholders. From the agricultural point of view the year 1905 has been favorable ; certain lines of railway have seen their receipts augmented, and the total of the kilometrical guarantees paid by the Government was diminished by £57,443, as shown in tbe following statement :—

The sales of the Régie have grown in notable proportions, and the receipts of the Ottoman Publie Debt have likewise shown an increase, from which the Government is the first to profit. I am pleased to be able to state that our relations with the Imperial Government continue satisfactory. The arrangement for the service of the Maoedonian Treasury commenced in March, 1905—centralizes in the hands of the bank the receipts and expenses of the three Vilayets. We are glad to say that this method works well. Our activity in the provinces has had during the year 1905 a very considerable enlargement, arising not only from the creation of several new agencies and offices, but also from the marked develop * men of the operations of the previously existing agencies, which has given us much encouragement.

We have since the commencement of the present year created new agencies at Kutahia, Xanthi, Tripoli in Barbary, Erzeroum, Caiffa, Aintab, and Kerassund, of which several are already opened. Notwithstanding the initial cost of establishing and administering new agencies, we are of opinion that we ought still to pursue the policy of assisting the Government in developing the resources of the Empire. It has to be borne in mind, however, that the extension of our sphere of action, alluring as the prospect mar be. entails considerable responsibilities and necessitates much pre occupation ; the special requirements of each district and the training and selection of a suitable staff are matters demanding the exercise of judgment and caution, to say nothing of the time which must elapse before a new branch can become remunerative. The deposits of the public continue to show a considerable increase, notwithstanding the active competition of new banke which are allowing higher rates of interest than ours, and we consider that this redounds much to the credit of the bank. I take this opportunity, on behalf of the committee, to thank the managers at the head offices at home and abroad, as well as of the various branches, for their continued close attention to their duties. They have been and are ably sapported by a loyal and trusted staff. In these days of keen com- petition the calls upon the staff of a large institution most be more- frequent than formerly. I am certain that, with our staff constituted as it is, we shall not make those calls in vain, and we shall be always ready to recognize any initiative on their part which in- creases the earning power of the bank. During the present year we have elected as a member of the general committee the Hon. Herbert Lawrence (brother of the Hon. Henry Lawrence, who for many years until his death was & member of the board). Mr. Her- bert Lawrence’s election is submitted for confirmation by you to day. I have every confidence th t he will prove of great value to the board. I now, gentlemen, beg to move : “Tlfcat tha report and accounts now read be received and adopted ; that the dividend for the year ending December 31st, 190S, is fixed at 16s. per share, and that this dividend be paid in Constantinople, London and Paris on July 3rd, 1906.” (Applause.)
Mone. George Heine seconded the résolution, which was carried unanimously.

The Chairman next proposed that the Baron Hottiuguer and Mone. Pyrame Naville be re elected members of the general committee. Barou Hottingue', he said, was a very distinguished Frenchman. He had been connected with this bank since its commencement, and had been its president in Paris since the year 1902.
Sir W. Lawrence Young seconded the motion, and it was unanimously agreed to.
On the motion of the Chairman, seconded by the Hon. G. J. Gosohen, the Hon. Herbert A. Lawrence was unanimously elected a member of the general committee.

The Chairman : The next resolution is of a special character, and before putting it I have to state that I have been informed by the в irutioeers, who have been properly appointed, that the meeting is constituted in accordance with the statutes for this special purpose. The resolution is -, “That the prolongation of the existence of the company until the year 1925, or such further date as may be decided upon by the committee, be and is hereby authorized.” That is the resolution that I beg to move.
This was seconded by Mous. Raoul Mallet, and carried unanimously.

Mr. A. Hood proposed a vote of thanks to the chairman, the general committ:o and the staff. He referred to this wo k which was required to produce nearly half a inillim sterling of profit, which he was sure 'every member of the staff had done his share in producing. He thought, therefore, they ought to remember not only the staff in Constantinople, Paris and Load in, but also those in charge of the various branches. (Hear, hear.)
Mr. A. J. Allen seconded the motion, which was cordially adopted.
The Chairman acknowledged the compliment, and stated that the vote of thanks which had been so unanimously passed would be conveyed to all the members of the staff.
The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GEM SYNDICATE LITIGATION.
div.p: ACTION DISMISSED.

The action by Mr. Edwin William Streeter against the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate, Ltd., was concluded last Wednesday in the Chancery Division before Mr. Justice Neville. Plaintiff claimed a declaration that the company’s rights under an agreement had lapsed and that the company had no right oi title to a concession and prospecting ‘license.

His Lordship, in giving judgment, said that, according to the agreement (dated 19th March, 1903), the syndicate became entitled to the option of acquiring the plaintiff’s concession from the Egyptian Government. Up to the 35th September, 1904, was the period fixed for completion, but before its -expiration plaintiff and the company entered into ten agreement with the Nile Development Syndicate, Ltd., and the time for the completion by the latter was extended till September, 1905, to which extension plaintiff and the defendant company were parties. The Nile Development Syndicate exercised its option, but when it came to the end of the extended time the syndicate was unable to complete its Contract, the result being that the plaintiff and defendant company reverted to their original agreement. It appeareAto the Lordship that according to the agreement of 7th December, 1904, plaintiff joined with the defendant company in the proposal to sell the concession, or. in other words, giving .the option to sell to the Nile Development Syndicate. The agreement of 16th February, 1905, was entered into with a dear recognition of the existence of the principal agreement His Lordship could not make the declaration asked for in the statement of claim, and so far as that was concerned the plaintiff’s case failed. In reference to the claim for moneys, he advised counsel on both sides to come to an arrangement as to the amount for which judgment ahold be given, and in view of that he would adjourn that question. SC far as the action to enforce his security was concerned plaintiff would get his costs, but otherwise the action would be dismissed with costs.

div.head: NEW ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: IL DIAVOLO IN CORPO.

The above piece was given on Wednesday night before a well filled house and proved an excellent evening’s entertainment, j edging from the frequent applause metedoutto the artistes. Marenoo's tuneful operetta was well rendered both by singers and orchestra and the staging was, as usual, much above the average for Cairo1. The second act is particularly worthy of mention in this respect, and much credit is due to those responsible for it. Both Signore Baldi and Calligaris performed up to their reputation, the latter delivering two or three notchy songs in very good style. The same may be said of Signori Piraocini and Urbano, who were again the life and soul of the pieoe. They were well seconded by Sig. Saochi, as the Duke, who acted and sang admirably, especially in the scene in the hot with Beita, though his efforts were not folly appreciated by the audience. The chorus was fair and the two dances given in the second act quite delighted the audience, who called for an encore.

We would suggest that the management should make an effort to finish; somewhat earlier, for several people seem to find it too much to remain at the theatre till 12.45, and we quite agree with them. Perhaps this would be remedied by starting a little earlier and curtailing the entr’actes.
La Stiratrice is billed for to night, the ever- popular Geisha tor Saturday, fallowed by the Diavolo in Corpo on Sunday night, with La Stiratrice as a matinée.
